head.title: Coast Guard Rescues 46 on Boat Off Haiti

hedline.hl1: Coast Guard Rescues 46 on Boat Off Haiti

abstract.p: United States Coast Guard cutter crew rescues 44 Haitians and 2 freelance journalists from sailboat en route to Florida; Coast Guard officials board boat in international waters, follow it into Bahamian territory, and order it evacuated after determining that boat was sinking; journalists are Mike Finkel, reporter, and Chris Anderson, photographer, on assignment for The New York Times Magazine to chronicle kind of journey growing number of Haitians are making to America (M)

block.p: The crew of a United States Coast Guard cutter has rescued 44 Haitians and 2 freelance journalists working for The New York Times from a sailboat en route to Florida, officials said yesterday.

Petty Officer Silvia Olvera, a Coast Guard spokeswoman, said the cutter Forward intercepted the boat on Sunday night about 18 miles northwest of Tortuga, Haiti. It was trying to sail from Haiti to the United States, she said.
The crew of a United States Coast Guard cutter has rescued 44 Haitians and 2 freelance journalists working for The New York Times from a sailboat en route to Florida, officials said yesterday.

Petty Officer Silvia Olvera, a Coast Guard spokeswoman, said the cutter Forward intercepted the boat on Sunday night about 18 miles northwest of Tortuga, Haiti. It was trying to sail from Haiti to the United States, she said.

Coast Guard officers boarded the boat in international waters and followed it into Bahamian territory. There, officers from the cutter determined that the 35-foot boat had to be evacuated because it was slowly sinking, Petty Officer Olvera said.
The 39 Haitian men, five Haitian women and the two American journalists were offered food, water and medical attention and then were turned over to Bahamian officials on Tuesday morning.

Mike Finkel, a reporter, and Chris Anderson, a photographer, were on assignment for The New York Times Magazine to chronicle the kind of journey a growing number of Haitians are making to America, said Adam Moss, editor of the magazine.
